title: 1929-A
statement: A. Sasha and the Beautiful Arraytime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputSasha decided to give his girlfriend an array $$$a_1, a_2, \\ldots, a_n$$$. He found out that his girlfriend evaluates thebeautyof the array as the sum of the values $$$(a_i - a_{i - 1})$$$ for all integers $$$i$$$ from $$$2$$$ to $$$n$$$.Help Sasha and tell him the maximum beauty of the array $$$a$$$ that he can obtain, if he can rearrange its elements in any way.InputEach test consists of multiple test cases. The first line contains a single integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\le t \\le 500$$$) — the number of test cases. The description of the test cases follows.The first line of each test case contains a single integer $$$n$$$ ($$$2 \\leq n \\leq 100$$$) — the length of the array $$$a$$$.The second line of each test case contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$a_1, a_2, \\ldots, a_n$$$ ($$$1 \\leq a_i \\leq 10^9$$$) — the elements of the array $$$a$$$.OutputFor each test case, output a single integer — the maximum beauty of the array $$$a$$$ that can be obtained.ExampleInput532 1 3369 69 695100 54 80 43 9043 4 3 322 1Output2 0 57 1 1NoteIn the first test case, the elements of the array $$$a$$$ can be rearranged to make $$$a = [1, 2, 3]$$$. Then its beauty will be equal to $$$(a_2 - a_1) + (a_3 - a_2) = (2 - 1) + (3 - 2) = 2$$$.In the second test case, there is no need to rearrange the elements of the array $$$a$$$. Then its beauty will be equal to $$$0$$$.

processed.result: You are given a list of numbers.  You can rearrange the list in any order. The score of the list is the sum of the differences between each number and the number before it (starting from the second number). What is the highest possible score you can achieve?

You are given an array of $n$ integers ($n \ge 2$).  The beauty of the array is defined as the sum of the differences between consecutive elements, from the second element to the last element.  

For example, if the array is $[1, 2, 3]$, the beauty is $(2-1) + (3-2) = 2$.

Find the maximum possible beauty of the array after rearranging its elements in any way.
